docs.lead_paragraph: With ephedra off the shelves and low-fat and low-carb diets getting you nowhere, you might be tempted to turn to a supplement called conjugated linoleic acid, or C.L.A., that has received an increasing amount of attention both in scientific and lay circles in recent years. The supplement has been widely promoted in alternative medicine circles and on the Internet as an aid to weight loss and muscle building and as a deterrent to heart disease, diabetes and cancer.

headline.main: Of Mice, Men and 'Magic' Diet Supplements

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses conjugated linoleic acid, unsaturated fatty acid that occurs naturally in milk and meat of animals, and its reported impact on weight loss and muscle building; CLA was first studied in 1978 by Dr Michael W Pariza, University of Wisconsin food scientist who suggested that it could promote overall better health; studies on nutrient are contradictory and suggest that although CLA has potential benefits, current health risks outweigh benefits of using supplements; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The evidence on conjugated linoleic acid, a supplement that has received an increasing amount of attention in recent years, is far from clear.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks in part to television shows like ''I Want a Famous Face'' on MTV, ''The Swan'' on Fox and ''Extreme Makeover'' on ABC, cosmetic surgery is more popular than ever. And children and teenagers are not immune to the trend. The number of cosmetic surgeries performed on people 18 and under reached 74,233 in 2003, a 14 percent increase from 2000, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Girls and boys as young as 6 get plastic surgery to flatten protruding ears. Adolescents of 13 or 14 have nose jobs. And nearly 3,700 breast augmentation surgeries were performed on teenage girls last year, according to the society. Almost as many teenage boys -- 3,300 -- had overly developed breasts reduced.

headline.main: How Young Is Too Young to Have a Nose Job and Breast Implants?

docs.abstract: American Society of Plastic Surgeons reports 14 percent increase in number of plastic surgeries done on people ages 18 and younger in 2003 over 2000; Dr Steven J Pearlman, American Academy of Facial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery and practicing facial plastic surgeon in New York City, suggests that doctors speak with patients alone to ensure that surgery is their wish and not parents; reasons why young people may pursue cosmetic surgery, including breast augmentation and nose jobs, discussed; age at which surgeries can safely be performed for various corrections described; ethics of elective, cosmetic surgery for young people remain open for debate (M)
docs.snippet: Cosmetic surgery is more popular than ever. And children and teenagers are not immune to the trend.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF FACIAL PLASTIC AND RECONSTRUCTIVE SURGERY

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Hypnosis can help you stop smoking. THE FACTS -- Quitting smoking is easy, Mark Twain once said, ''I've done it a thousand times.'' In actuality, anyone who has ever tried knows how challenging it can be. Nicotine is notoriously addictive. More than three-quarters of smokers relapse a few times, no matter what they try. Hypnosis seems to be about as effective as many other techniques, and that means not very, research suggests.
docs.abstract: Hypnosis can help smokers quit if they are highly motivated to stop smoking; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Hypnosis may be helpful in quitting smoking, but as with other techniques, you have to be highly motivated.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Alfred Szymanski could not seem to get his blood pressure under control. He ran 10 miles a week, stuck to a healthy diet and was on a hypertension medication, all to no avail. His doctor suggested switching medications, but Mr. Szymanski, wary of side effects, decided to try something he had always wondered about: acupuncture. After three 20-minute sessions, each covered by his medical plan, his blood pressure plunged 20 points.
docs.abstract: Acupuncture, which has been shunned by mainstream medical community, is gaining legitimate ground with several new studies showing acupuncture's benefits; Kaiser Family Foundation and Health Research and Educational Trust survey finds that nearly 50 percent of workers have acupuncture included in health benefits, which is up from only 30 percent two years ago; acupuncture is only alternative therapy to have extensive government-financed testing from as early as 1970's; animals are now being given acupuncture to relieve pain; Chicago veterinarian Barbara Royal holds her business administering acupuncture to animals is non-stop; common uses for acupuncture described; proposed industry regulations discussed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Acupuncture, long shunned by mainstream medicine, is slowly gaining ground in doctors' offices around the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Group therapy offers important benefits for women fighting breast cancer -- but a longer life is not one of them, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in The Journal of Clinical Oncology, the researchers said they had been unable to reproduce the finding of some earlier studies that the therapy increased the survival time in breast cancer patients. But the study did re-establish the value of therapy as a tool for such patients.
docs.abstract: Dr David W Kissane, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center psychiatry and behavioral sciences chairman, leads study on impact of group therapy on survival rate for breast cancer patients; research, contrary to earlier studies, does not find women participating in group therapy to live longer; study does, however, find that quality of life is greatly improved by therapy; findings are published in Journal of Clinical Oncology (S)
docs.snippet: Group therapy offers important benefits for women fighting breast cancer  but a longer life is not one of them, researchers have reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: That dollop of wasabi on your sushi may feel like a blast of decongestant, but researchers have found that it does not really clear the sinuses. In fact, the researchers report, the condiment, often called Japanese horseradish, actually causes a bit of congestion. The study, by Dr. David S. Cameron and Dr. Raul M. Cruz of the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland, Calif., was presented last week at a meeting of the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Foundation.
docs.abstract: Dr David S Cameron and Dr Raul M Cruz of Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland, Calif, lead study that shows eating wasabi actually deepens congestion rather than clearing nasal passages as commonly thought; study was presented at meeting of American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Ffoundation; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: That dollop of wasabi on your sushi may feel like a blast of decongestant, but researchers have found that it does not really clear the sinuses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Men who drink red wine regularly appear to have a reduced risk of prostate cancer, a new study reports. The study, which appears online in The International Journal of Cancer, found that a glass of wine a day appeared to cut the risk of the cancer in half.
docs.abstract: Dr Janet L Stanford of Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center leads study that finds consumption of four or more glasses of red wine per week significantly reduces risk of prostate cancer; research is published online in International Journal of Cancer; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Men who drink red wine regularly appear to have a reduced risk of prostate cancer, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: British researchers have trained dogs to detect bladder cancer by sniffing human urine, opening up the possibility that dogs -- or electronic noses modeled on their snouts -- may one day be used to detect the disease. The study, published in the British medical journal BMJ on Saturday, is the first to demonstrate scientifically that dogs can detect cancer through smell, its authors said.

headline.main: Moist Nose Shows Promise in Tracking Down Cancers

docs.abstract: Recent study conducted at Amersham Hospital in Buckinghamshire, England and published in BMJ, British medical journal, suggests that dogs can be trained to detect cancer through smell; other studies have also found that some dogs are highly accurate at smelling chemicals present when patients have certain types of cancer; use of dogs in detecting cancer on large-scale is uncertain, but researchers hold that more studies should be conducted to determine possible benefits; photos (M)
docs.snippet: British researchers have trained dogs to detect bladder cancer by sniffing human urine, opening up the possibility that dogs may one day be used to detect the disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just going out regularly for an easy walk appears to help elderly people ward off a decline in their mental abilities, two new studies have found. One of the studies, which tracked the health and exercise habits of more than 18,000 women over a period of about 12 years, found that those who walked regularly had the mental acuity usually associated with people several years younger.
docs.abstract: Dr Jennifer Weuve, Harvard University School of Public Health epidemiologist, leads study that shows that women who walk at least six hours per week have 20 percent lower risk of developing mental impairments; similar study, by Dr Robert D Abbott of University of Virginia School of Medicine, finds individuals who walk least have highest risk of developing dementia; both studies are published in Journal of the American Medical Assn; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Just going out regularly for an easy walk appears to help elderly people ward off a decline in their mental abilities, two new studies have found.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Curing M.S.: How Science Is Solving the Mysteries of Multiple Sclerosis,'' by Dr. Howard L. Weiner. Crown; $24.95. An Israeli writer once told Dr. Weiner that the disease he was studying, multiple sclerosis, was a monster. ''You cut it here, it grows there,'' the writer told the doctor. ''You think it is down, but it rises again. You believe you understand why it behaves the way it does, but you are wrong.''
docs.abstract: Dr Howard L Weiner book Curing MS: How Science Is Solving the Mysteries of Multiple Sclerosis is detailed account of disease, which is number one cause of paralysis in young people in America; emphasizes early treatment, which until recently has been standard; new clinical studies, however, show it may not always be best course of action; progression of MS described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A new book explores multiple sclerosis, the devastating, unpredictable and progressive disease of the nervous system.
